10870Journal of Chemical CrystallographyJ Chem Crystallogr1074-15421572-8854Springer USBostons10870-008-9332-z933210.1007/s10870-008-9332-zOriginal PaperThe Solid-state Structure of a 4,13-Diaza-18-crown-6 NaI Complex: A Unique Chain-link AssemblyMeadowsEric S.1LevinBrock D.2ElliottElizabeth K.1BarbourLeonard J.3GokelGeorge W.124egrid.4367.60000000123557002School of MedicineWashington University63110St. LouisMOUSAgrid.266757.70000000114809378Departments of Chemistry & Biochemistry and BiologyUniversity of Missouri – St. LouisOne University Blvd.63121St. LouisMOUSAgrid.11956.3a000000012214904XDepartment of ChemistryUniversity of Stellenbosch7602MatielandSouth Africagrid.266757.70000000114809378Center for NanoscienceUniversity of Missouri – St. LouisOne University Blvd.63121St. LouisMOUSAgokelg@umsl.edu2232008620083864254294320082120084320082232008© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20082008Abstract

Reported within is the crystal structure of 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 and NaI (P21/c; a = 7.0732(5) Å, b = 15.4058(10) Å, c = 9.9605(6) Å, b = 96.7950(10)°, V = 1077.75(12) Å3, Z = 2). The structure was obtained serendipitously from a crystallization attempt of these two components in the presence of indole. There are two non-equivalent sodium cations, one encapsulated within the diazacrown, and a second cation linking two adjacent diazacrowns and coordinating to both. The sodium cations are also linked through a water bridge. This leads to the formation of infinite 1–D chains in which iodide counterions occupy the space between the chains. This is the first reported example of an unsubstituted 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 encapsulating Na+. The first structure of 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 and NaI containing two symmetrically inequivalent Na+ ions, only one of which is encapsulated by the diazacrown, is reported.

Index Abstract

The first structure of 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 and NaI containing two symmetrically inequivalent Na+ ions, only one of which is encapsulated by the diazacrown, is reported

Literally thousands of oxygen, nitrogen, and sulfur containing macrocycles have been prepared [1] in the forty years since Pedersen’s landmark report of crown ethers [2]. During the ensuing decades, host-guest and supramolecular chemistry have become dominant themes in modern science. Macrocycles have evolved from being individual entities meriting separate study [3] to being building blocks in increasingly complex structures [4, 5]. Hundreds of solid-state structures have been reported of macrocycles, their complexes with numerous guests, and various assemblies of these building blocks. Even after 40 years, new structures and applications continue to be reported [6–10].

Diaza-18-crown-6 (1) holds a special place in macrocyclic chemistry. It is the key building block for [2.2.2]-cryptand [11, 12] and for many bibracchial lariat ethers [13]. The latter has been of special interest in our laboratory for many years. The two-armed lariat ethers have recently proved to be of inestimable value in our study of alkali metal cation-pi interactions [14, 15]. We used diaza-18-crown-6 molecules as the basis of bibracchial lariat ethers having arene-terminated sidearms [16]. Attachment of the sidearms at nitrogen gave the receptor molecules conformational flexibility, which would not have been possible had the sidearms been attached at carbon.

During the course of these studies, we attempted to form non-covalently linked cation-pi complexes. Hrncir, Rogers, and Atwood had reported a dibenzo-18-crown-6 complex of potassium cation in which the latter’s apical position was occupied by a pi-bound benzene molecule [17]. We thus attempted to co-crystallize 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 (1),1 18 alkali metal salts, and arenes such as benzene and indole in the hope of forming self-assembled pi-complexes. The unique, one-dimensional chain of diaza-18-crown-6, NaI, and water reported here resulted from such an experiment.

To our knowledge, only four structures of unsubstituted, uncomplexed 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 have been reported. These include a hydrated crown (NISHUS), [18] the earliest structure (TOAZOC) reported in 1972 by Herceg and Weiss, [19] and two more recent non-complexed structures in which the free crown is in a pseudo-D3d arrangement (TOAZOC01, [20] TOAZOC03 [21]). We were surprised to find no structure reported for 1 complexing any alkali metal halide. We were also unable to find any Na+ complex of 1 irrespective of counterion. A search of the CSD revealed 13 complexes of the type 1 · K+ in which the anion was SCN− (KOXDZO, [22] KOXDZO01 [23]), I3− (LIMRAA [24]), or a complex organometallic species (MAMNAP, [25] MANKOC, [26] NUQWUR, [27] OCIRUN, [28] OCISAU, [28] OCISEY, [28] QEWCIE, [29] QORWUP, [30] SUYTIP, [31] and XODSIS [32]).

Of course, diaza-18-crown-6 is a subunit in [2.2.2]-cryptand and numerous alkali metal halide complexes are known for this three-dimensional receptor. The lack of Na+-complex structures is made more remarkable by the fact the more than 400 structures are reported in the Cambridge Structural Database that incorporate diaza-18-crown-6 as an element or subunit.

Experimental

All reagents were the best grade commercially available and were distilled, recrystallized, or used without further purification, as appropriate. Crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were prepared from commercially available solvents and salts were used without further purification.

4,13-Diaza-18-crown-6 was synthesized as previously reported [33]

Synthesis of 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 · NaI, 1

Compound 1 (4.8 mg; 0.018 mmol), indole (4.2 mg; 0.036 mmol) and NaI (2.7 mg; 0.018 mmol) were dissolved in CH3COCH3 and slow evaporation led to the formation of crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction.

X-Ray Crystallography

Data were collected at 173(2) K on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer (ω scan mode Mo KI radiation, λ = 0.7107 Å) (Table 1). Data were corrected for absorption using the program SADABS [34]. Structure solution and refinement proceeded similarly for all structures (SHELX-97 software [35] using the X-Seed [36] interface). Direct methods yielded all non-hydrogen atoms of the asymmetric unit. These atoms were refined anisotropically (full-matrix least-squares method on F2). Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions with their isotropic thermal parameters riding on those of their parent atoms. Mean planes of the macrocycles were calculated with PARST [37]. All X-ray structure figures were prepared with X-Seed and POV-Ray [38].

Results and Discussion

We reported what is now the standard method for the preparation of 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 in 1989 [33]. Using that compound, we attempted to make a self-assembled cation-pi complex by mixing 1, two equivalents of indole, and NaI in acetone. The mixture was allowed to stand during slow evaporation of the solvent. The hope was that the self-assembled analog of the complex 2 · NaI [39] would be formed. The structures of 1 and 2 are shown (Fig. 1).

When either Na+ or K+ is bound within the macroring of 2, the sidearms fold inward, above and below the macroring plane, permitting the benzene rings to serve as apical pi-donors. The two arenes were essentially parallel and the line connecting the centroids passed through the alkali metal cation. It was hoped that by using electron rich indole with 1, a similar structure would form, although the arene and macroring would not be covalently linked. Instead, a complex lacking indole and having the stoichiometry 1 · NaI(H2O)2 formed. In most crown ether complexes of alkali metal cations, the macrocycle forms a medial belt about the cation and the apical position is occupied either by an anion, a solvent molecule, or by a water molecule that is H-bonded to the anion. The KI complex of 3, the arenes of which are electron poor, forms a complex in which K+ is bound within the macrocycle. Each ring-bound cation is in contact with two apical iodide ions, creating an infinite, one-dimensional (K − I)n chain.

In the structure reported here, the Na+ cation is octahedral (Fig. 2). The apical donors for the ring-bound Na+ are the two macroring nitrogen atoms of 1. Two of the Na+ atom’s medial positions are occupied by macroring oxygen and the other two sites are occupied by coordinated water molecules. Each ring-bound Na+ atom is adjacent to a second Na+ atom that is coordinated by six oxygens: four from two adjacent macrocycles and two from bridging water molecules.

For the ring-bound sodium ion, the Na-N distance is 2.65 Å (Table 2), compared with a mean of 2.76 Å for structures in the CSD containing the diazacrown fragment bound to sodium. Because the CSD contains no unsubstituted diazacrown sodium complex, the bond distances are the average of all non-cryptand structures containing the diazacrown fragment [40]. The Na–O (crown ether) distance is 2.54 Å, compared with an average of 2.50 Å for the reported structures. The bond distance of the coordinated water molecule is 2.37 Å. There are no previously reported diazacrown structures with water coordinated to the cation, but the mean Na⋯OH2 contact distance for 18-crown-6 structures is 2.31 Å.

There are two remarkable features of this structure. First, it is very unusual for a cation to be shared among crown ethers rather than being enveloped by a single macrocycle. When linkage of cations does occur, it is typically through a counteranion. Second, rather than forming a chain of cations and anions, this system has formed a linear chain of sodium cations. In fact, the Na-Na-Na angle is exactly 180° and each sodium is 3.54 Å from the adjacent one. The water molecules that bridge the adjacent sodium cations differ, however. The two pairs of Na–OW–Na distances are 2.37 Å, 2.42 Å, angle = 95.2° and 2.48 Å, 2.54 Å and 89.5°. A search of the CSD revealed 39 bridging Na–OW–Na interactions ranging from ∼65–180°. The median value was 94.1° and the mean was 96.8°. The values for the present structure are clearly as expected.

Conclusion

To our knowledge, this is the first solid-state structure of unsubstituted 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 complexing Na+, i.e., 1 · NaI. In contrast, there are 17 structures reported for 1 complexing K+ and there are several structures of Na+ complexed by substituted diaza-18-crown-6 derivatives. It appears that the 1 · NaI structure is unique among the more than 3000 crown ether-containing crystal structures whose coordinates were deposited in the CSD. The only related example we could find was a catena-((μ2-dicyclohexano-18-crown-6)-bis(phenoxy-potassium)) structure (CSD: DUNSOU), [41] in which bridging phenol molecules link dicyclohexanocrown-bound potassium cations.

The median value was 94.1° and the mean was 96.8°. The values for the present structure are clearly as expected.ConclusionTo our knowledge, this is the first solid-state structure of unsubstituted 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 complexing Na+, i.e., 1 ⋅ NaI. In contrast, there are 17 structures reported for 1 complexing K+ and there are several structures of Na+ complexed by substituted diaza-18-crown-6 derivatives. It appears that the 1 ⋅ NaI structure is unique among the more than 3000 crown ether-containing crystal structures whose coordinates were deposited in the CSD. The only related example we could find was a catena-((μ2-dicyclohexano-18-crown-6)-bis(phenoxy-potassium)) structure (CSD: DUNSOU), [41] in which bridging phenol molecules link dicyclohexanocrown-bound potassium cations.Crystallographic DataCCDC...contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. elements.content: Reported within is the crystal structure of 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 and NaI (P21/c; a = 7.0732(5) Å, b = 15.4058(10) Å, c = 9.9605(6) Å, b = 96.7950(10)°, V = 1077.75(12) Å3, Z = 2). The structure was obtained serendipitously from a crystallization attempt of these two components in the presence of indole. There are two non-equivalent sodium cations, one encapsulated within the diazacrown, and a second cation linking two adjacent diazacrowns and coordinating to both. The sodium cations are also linked through a water bridge. This leads to the formation of infinite 1–D chains in which iodide counterions occupy the space between the chains. This is the first reported example of an unsubstituted 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 encapsulating Na+. The first structure of 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 and NaI containing two symmetrically inequivalent Na+ ions, only one of which is encapsulated by the diazacrown, is reported.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Reported within is the crystal structure of 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 and NaI (P21/c; a = 7.0732(5) Å, b = 15.4058(10) Å, c = 9.9605(6) Å, b = 96.7950(10)°, V = 1077.75(12) Å3, Z = 2). The structure was obtained serendipitously from a crystallization attempt of these two components in the presence of indole. There are two non-equivalent sodium cations, one encapsulated within the diazacrown, and a second cation linking two adjacent diazacrowns and coordinating to both. The sodium cations are also linked through a water bridge. This leads to the formation of infinite 1-D chains in which iodide counterions occupy the space between the chains. This is the first reported example of an unsubstituted 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 encapsulating Na+. The first structure of 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 and NaI containing two symmetrically inequivalent Na+ ions, only one of which is encapsulated by the diazacrown, is reported.

Introduction

Literally thousands of oxygen, nitrogen, and sulfur containing macrocycles have been prepared [1] in the forty years since Pedersen’s landmark report of crown ethers [2]. During the ensuing decades, host-guest and supramolecular chemistry have become dominant themes in modern science. Macrocycles have evolved from being individual entities meriting separate study [3] to being building blocks in increasingly complex structures [4, 5]. Hundreds of solid-state structures have been reported of macrocycles, their complexes with numerous guests, and various assemblies of these building blocks. Even after 40 years, new structures and applications continue to be reported [6–10].

Introduction

Literally thousands of oxygen, nitrogen, and sulfur containing macrocycles have been prepared [1] in the forty years since Pedersen's landmark report of crown ethers [2]. During the ensuing decades, host-guest and supramolecular chemistry have become dominant themes in modern science. Macrocycles have evolved from being individual entities meriting separate study [3] to being building blocks in increasingly complex structures [4, 5]. Hundreds of solid-state structures have been reported of macrocycles, their complexes with numerous guests, and various assemblies of these building blocks. Even after 40 years, new structures and applications continue to be reported [6-10].

elements.content: Diaza-18-crown-6 (1) holds a special place in macrocyclic chemistry. It is the key building block for [2.2.2]-cryptand [11, 12] and for many bibracchial lariat ethers [13]. The latter has been of special interest in our laboratory for many years. The two-armed lariat ethers have recently proved to be of inestimable value in our study of alkali metal cation-pi interactions [14, 15]. We used diaza-18-crown-6 molecules as the basis of bibracchial lariat ethers having arene-terminated sidearms [16]. Attachment of the sidearms at nitrogen gave the receptor molecules conformational flexibility, which would not have been possible had the sidearms been attached at carbon.
elements.clean_text: Diaza-18-crown-6 (1) holds a special place in macrocyclic chemistry. It is the key building block for [2.2.2]-cryptand [11, 12] and for many bibracchial lariat ethers [13]. The latter has been of special interest in our laboratory for many years. The two-armed lariat ethers have recently proved to be of inestimable value in our study of alkali metal cation-pi interactions [14, 15]. We used diaza-18-crown-6 molecules as the basis of bibracchial lariat ethers having arene-terminated sidearms [16]. Attachment of the sidearms at nitrogen gave the receptor molecules conformational flexibility, which would not have been possible had the sidearms been attached at carbon.

elements.content: During the course of these studies, we attempted to form non-covalently linked cation-pi complexes. Hrncir, Rogers, and Atwood had reported a dibenzo-18-crown-6 complex of potassium cation in which the latter’s apical position was occupied by a pi-bound benzene molecule [17]. We thus attempted to co-crystallize 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 (1),1 18 alkali metal salts, and arenes such as benzene and indole in the hope of forming self-assembled pi-complexes. The unique, one-dimensional chain of diaza-18-crown-6, NaI, and water reported here resulted from such an experiment.
elements.clean_text: During the course of these studies, we attempted to form non-covalently linked cation-pi complexes. Hrncir, Rogers, and Atwood had reported a dibenzo-18-crown-6 complex of potassium cation in which the latter's apical position was occupied by a pi-bound benzene molecule [17]. We thus attempted to co-crystallize 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 (1),1 18 alkali metal salts, and arenes such as benzene and indole in the hope of forming self-assembled pi-complexes. The unique, one-dimensional chain of diaza-18-crown-6, NaI, and water reported here resulted from such an experiment.

elements.content: To our knowledge, only four structures of unsubstituted, uncomplexed 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 have been reported. These include a hydrated crown (NISHUS), [18] the earliest structure (TOAZOC) reported in 1972 by Herceg and Weiss, [19] and two more recent non-complexed structures in which the free crown is in a pseudo-D3d arrangement (TOAZOC01, [20] TOAZOC03 [21]). We were surprised to find no structure reported for 1 complexing any alkali metal halide. We were also unable to find any Na+ complex of 1 irrespective of counterion. A search of the CSD revealed 13 complexes of the type 1 · K+ in which the anion was SCN− (KOXDZO, [22] KOXDZO01 [23]), I3− (LIMRAA [24]), or a complex organometallic species (MAMNAP, [25] MANKOC, [26] NUQWUR, [27] OCIRUN, [28] OCISAU, [28] OCISEY, [28] QEWCIE, [29] QORWUP, [30] SUYTIP, [31] and XODSIS [32]).

These include a hydrated crown (NISHUS), [18] the earliest structure (TOAZOC) reported in 1972 by Herceg and Weiss, [19] and two more recent non-complexed structures in which the free crown is in a pseudo-D3d arrangement (TOAZOC01, [20] TOAZOC03 [21]). We were surprised to find no structure reported for 1 complexing any alkali metal halide. We were also unable to find any Na+ complex of 1 irrespective of counterion. A search of the CSD revealed 13 complexes of the type 1 ⋅ K+ in which the anion was SCN- (KOXDZO, [22] KOXDZO01 [23]), I3- (LIMRAA [24]), or a complex organometallic species (MAMNAP, [25] MANKOC, [26] NUQWUR, [27] OCIRUN, [28] OCISAU, [28] OCISEY, [28] QEWCIE, [29] QORWUP, [30] SUYTIP, [31] and XODSIS [32]).

elements.content: Of course, diaza-18-crown-6 is a subunit in [2.2.2]-cryptand and numerous alkali metal halide complexes are known for this three-dimensional receptor. The lack of Na+-complex structures is made more remarkable by the fact the more than 400 structures are reported in the Cambridge Structural Database that incorporate diaza-18-crown-6 as an element or subunit.

elements.content:
4,13-Diaza-18-crown-6 was synthesized as previously reported [33]

Synthesis of 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 · NaI, 1

Compound 1 (4.8 mg; 0.018 mmol), indole (4.2 mg; 0.036 mmol) and NaI (2.7 mg; 0.018 mmol) were dissolved in CH3COCH3 and slow evaporation led to the formation of crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction.

Synthesis of 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 ⋅ NaI, 1

Compound 1 (4.8 mg; 0.018 mmol), indole (4.2 mg; 0.036 mmol) and NaI (2.7 mg; 0.018 mmol) were dissolved in CH3COCH3 and slow evaporation led to the formation of crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction.

elements.content: Data were collected at 173(2) K on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer (ω scan mode Mo KI radiation, λ = 0.7107 Å) (Table 1). Data were corrected for absorption using the program SADABS [34]. Structure solution and refinement proceeded similarly for all structures (SHELX-97 software [35] using the X-Seed [36] interface). Direct methods yielded all non-hydrogen atoms of the asymmetric unit. These atoms were refined anisotropically (full-matrix least-squares method on F2). Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions with their isotropic thermal parameters riding on those of their parent atoms. Mean planes of the macrocycles were calculated with PARST [37]. All X-ray structure figures were prepared with X-Seed and POV-Ray [38].
elements.clean_text:
X-Ray Crystallography

Data were collected at 173(2) K on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer (ω scan mode Mo KI radiation, λ = 0.7107 Å) (Table 1). Data were corrected for absorption using the program SADABS [34]. Structure solution and refinement proceeded similarly for all structures (SHELX-97 software [35] using the X-Seed [36] interface). Direct methods yielded all non-hydrogen atoms of the asymmetric unit. These atoms were refined anisotropically (full-matrix least-squares method on F2). Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions with their isotropic thermal parameters riding on those of their parent atoms. Mean planes of the macrocycles were calculated with PARST [37]. All X-ray structure figures were prepared with X-Seed and POV-Ray [38].

We reported what is now the standard method for the preparation of 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 in 1989 [33]. Using that compound, we attempted to make a self-assembled cation-pi complex by mixing 1, two equivalents of indole, and NaI in acetone. The mixture was allowed to stand during slow evaporation of the solvent. The hope was that the self-assembled analog of the complex 2 · NaI [39] would be formed. The structures of 1 and 2 are shown (Fig. 1).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

We reported what is now the standard method for the preparation of 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 in 1989 [33]. Using that compound, we attempted to make a self-assembled cation-pi complex by mixing 1, two equivalents of indole, and NaI in acetone. The mixture was allowed to stand during slow evaporation of the solvent. The hope was that the self-assembled analog of the complex 2 ⋅ NaI [39] would be formed. The structures of 1 and 2 are shown (Fig. 1).

elements.content: Compounds 1–3. Some diazacrowns used to encapsulate Na+ and K+
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1Compounds 1-3. Some diazacrowns used to encapsulate Na+ and K+

elements.content: When either Na+ or K+ is bound within the macroring of 2, the sidearms fold inward, above and below the macroring plane, permitting the benzene rings to serve as apical pi-donors. The two arenes were essentially parallel and the line connecting the centroids passed through the alkali metal cation. It was hoped that by using electron rich indole with 1, a similar structure would form, although the arene and macroring would not be covalently linked. Instead, a complex lacking indole and having the stoichiometry 1 · NaI(H2O)2 formed. In most crown ether complexes of alkali metal cations, the macrocycle forms a medial belt about the cation and the apical position is occupied either by an anion, a solvent molecule, or by a water molecule that is H-bonded to the anion. The KI complex of 3, the arenes of which are electron poor, forms a complex in which K+ is bound within the macrocycle. Each ring-bound cation is in contact with two apical iodide ions, creating an infinite, one-dimensional (K − I)n chain.

Instead, a complex lacking indole and having the stoichiometry 1 ⋅ NaI(H2O)2 formed. The KI complex of 3, the arenes of which are electron poor, forms a complex in which K+ is bound within the macrocycle. Each ring-bound cation is in contact with two apical iodide ions, creating an infinite, one-dimensional (K - I)n chain.

elements.content: In the structure reported here, the Na+ cation is octahedral (Fig. 2). The apical donors for the ring-bound Na+ are the two macroring nitrogen atoms of 1. Two of the Na+ atom’s medial positions are occupied by macroring oxygen and the other two sites are occupied by coordinated water molecules. Each ring-bound Na+ atom is adjacent to a second Na+ atom that is coordinated by six oxygens: four from two adjacent macrocycles and two from bridging water molecules.

Each ring-bound Na+ atom is adjacent to a second Na+ atom that is coordinated by six oxygens: four from two adjacent macrocycles and two from bridging water molecules.

elements.content: For the ring-bound sodium ion, the Na-N distance is 2.65 Å (Table 2), compared with a mean of 2.76 Å for structures in the CSD containing the diazacrown fragment bound to sodium. Because the CSD contains no unsubstituted diazacrown sodium complex, the bond distances are the average of all non-cryptand structures containing the diazacrown fragment [40]. The Na–O (crown ether) distance is 2.54 Å, compared with an average of 2.50 Å for the reported structures. The bond distance of the coordinated water molecule is 2.37 Å. There are no previously reported diazacrown structures with water coordinated to the cation, but the mean Na⋯OH2 contact distance for 18-crown-6 structures is 2.31 Å.

There are two remarkable features of this structure. First, it is very unusual for a cation to be shared among crown ethers rather than being enveloped by a single macrocycle. When linkage of cations does occur, it is typically through a counteranion. Second, rather than forming a chain of cations and anions, this system has formed a linear chain of sodium cations. In fact, the Na-Na-Na angle is exactly 180° and each sodium is 3.54 Å from the adjacent one. The water molecules that bridge the adjacent sodium cations differ, however. The two pairs of Na–OW–Na distances are 2.37 Å, 2.42 Å, angle = 95.2° and 2.48 Å, 2.54 Å and 89.5°. A search of the CSD revealed 39 bridging Na–OW–Na interactions ranging from ∼65–180°. The median value was 94.1° and the mean was 96.8°. The values for the present structure are clearly as expected.

elements.content: To our knowledge, this is the first solid-state structure of unsubstituted 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 complexing Na+, i.e., 1 · NaI. In contrast, there are 17 structures reported for 1 complexing K+ and there are several structures of Na+ complexed by substituted diaza-18-crown-6 derivatives. It appears that the 1 · NaI structure is unique among the more than 3000 crown ether-containing crystal structures whose coordinates were deposited in the CSD. The only related example we could find was a catena-((μ2-dicyclohexano-18-crown-6)-bis(phenoxy-potassium)) structure (CSD: DUNSOU), [41] in which bridging phenol molecules link dicyclohexanocrown-bound potassium cations.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

To our knowledge, this is the first solid-state structure of unsubstituted 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 complexing Na+, i.e., 1 ⋅ NaI. In contrast, there are 17 structures reported for 1 complexing K+ and there are several structures of Na+ complexed by substituted diaza-18-crown-6 derivatives. It appears that the 1 ⋅ NaI structure is unique among the more than 3000 crown ether-containing crystal structures whose coordinates were deposited in the CSD. The only related example we could find was a catena-((μ2-dicyclohexano-18-crown-6)-bis(phenoxy-potassium)) structure (CSD: DUNSOU), [41] in which bridging phenol molecules link dicyclohexanocrown-bound potassium cations.

cln_elements.content:
4,13-Diaza-18-crown-6 was synthesized as previously reported [33]

Synthesis of 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 · NaI, 1

Compound 1 (4.8 mg; 0.018 mmol), indole (4.2 mg; 0.036 mmol) and NaI (2.7 mg; 0.018 mmol) were dissolved in CH3COCH3 and slow evaporation led to the formation of crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction.
